column5: ['A Chego subject of the paljetter, living in Coenje Taij, situated at Saint Andries, and the mentioned Canden, has brought a slave meijd to the city to sell her, and because this belongs to the third Martha, and was slaughtered by the timmermans, therefore they have arrested the meid and the seller in the city; doing an inquiry about the case, they have confessed that Oettijmacherij Pandialakel Simon, and Welepenaddoe Antij, who have stolen the meid, and have handed her over to the Chego of the paljetter to sell her;']
column6: ['A subject of the paljetter in Coenje Taij, located in Saint Andries, and named Canden, has brought a slave meijd to the city to sell, and because it belongs to De Martha, and was raised by the timmermans geslagt, so one has seized the meid, and the seller in the city: andquest of the case doing, so we have been assured of the truth, that Oettijmacherij Pandialakel Simon, and Welepenaddoe Antij have stolen that meid, and have given her to the Chego of the paljetter to sell, these are the testimonies']
column7: ['A Chego subject of the paljetter residing in Coenje Taij on Saint Andries, and named Canden, has brought a slave meijd to the city to sell her, and because she belongs to trik De Martha, and is of the timmermans caste, the meid has been kept, as well as the seller, in the city; an inquest having been instituted, it has been informed to us for the truth, that Oettijmacherij Pandialakel Simon and Welepenaddoe Antij have stolen that meid and handed her over to the Chego of the paljetter to sell her, this are the declar']
column8: ["A certain subject of the palatine governor living in Coenje Taij, near St. Andrews and St. Canden, has led a slave girl to the city to sell her, and the girl belonged to Trijk De Martha, who was of the carpenter's lineage. They, therefore, arrested the girl, as well as the seller in the city. Upon questioning, they informed us for the truth that Oettijmacherij Pandialakel Simon, and Welepenaddoe Antij had stolen the girl and given her to the palatine governor's subject to sell in the city. These are the testimonies of the friends"]

column3: En bij de 16:e vraege van dies recollement hem gevraegt sijnde, dat indien den christen Antij, voorsz: jongen hem hadde gegeven om te verkopen, en naer aftrek van de helfte van d’prijs van ’t varken, 225. fan:s aan hem antij uit te keeren; waerom hij den in soo daenigen geval, gem: fan:s met sijn terugkomst van Chettua, aan gem: Antij niet heeft gegeven, of wanneer hij Antij [. . .] Paroe bij hem is gekomen? antwoorde hij in deser voegen, te weeten: Ik hebbe de 225.’ fan:s aan mijn swager gegeven, en toen ben ik nae Paroe gegaan.
column4: And to the 16th question of his verification – in which he was asked, that if the Christian Antij had given him the aforementioned jongen in order to sell him, and to give Antij 225 fanums after deduction of half of the price of the pig, why in that case he had not given the aforementioned Antij the mentioned fanums when he returned from Chettua or when Antij came to him [in] Paroe? – he answered in this way: I have given the 225 fanums to my brother-in-law, and then I went to Paroe.
column5: ['And to the 16th question of his verification, asked him, whether if the Christian Antij had given him the jongen to sell, and after deduction of the one-eighth of the price of the pig, 225 fanums would have had to return to him, Antij; whether in the case of such an occurrence, he did not give the aforementioned 225 fanums to the aforementioned Antij, or when Antij [. . .] came to him at Chettua? Answered he, as is written down here in addition: I returned the 225 fanums to my brother-in-law, and']
column6: ['And to the 16th question of this verification, asked whether if the Christian Antij, aforementioned jongen had given him to sell, and after deduction of half the price of the pig, the 225 fanums to pay to the aforementioned Antij; why he did not give the aforementioned fanums to Antij upon his return from Chettua, or when [....] Paroe came to me? He answered as follows: I gave the 225 fanums to my brother-in-law, and then I went to Paroe.']
column7: ['And when asked at the 16th question of his verification, that if the Christian Antij had given the jongen to him to sell, and after deduction of half of the price of the pig, 225 fanums to be paid to him Antij; why he in that case had not given the 225 fanums to the aforementioned Antij upon his return from Chettua, or when the aforementioned Antij came to Paroe? He answered in these words, to know that I have given the 225 fanums to my brother-in-law, and then I went to Paroe.']
column8: ['And when asked the 16th question of this recollection, whether if the Christian Antij, forenamed youth, had given him a pig to sell, and after deducting half the price of the pig, 225. florins to be returned to Antij; why he had not given it to Antij then, or when Antij [. . .] Paroe had come to him? he answered in these words, to wit: I have given the 225. florins to my father-in-law, and then I went to Paroe.']

column3: Voorts gevraegt zijnde, wat reden den attes:t heeft gehad om den jonge aantehouden, daar hij reets beleed een vrijgebooren christen te zijn, en of den attes:t niet weet, het van zijn pligt was geweest soo dadelijk daar van kennissse te geven aan den E:E: agtb: heer commandeur, en den fiscael, heeft bij daar op gerepliceerd, dat hij d’antwoord van den jonge gehoort hebbende, hem ten eerste heeft aangeraden, om zoodra den jood binnen quam, met hem na zijn E:E: agtb: te gaen, en aldaar zijn beklagt te doen, gelijk reets hier vooren vermelt staat, en dat hij daarvoor versoekt zulx dien jonge mag werden afgevraegt.
column4: Furthermore, being asked what reason the testifier had to arrest the jongen, because he already had professed to be a freeborn Christian, and whether the testifier does not know, that it was his duty to immediately inform the honourable lord commander, and the fiscal, of this, he had replied that hearing the answer of the jongen, he advised him, first, to go with him to the honourable lord as soon as the Jew entered, and make his complaint there, as has been stated before, and that he therefore requests that the jongen can be asked about this.
column5: ['Furthermore, having been asked being, what reason the testifier had to seize the jonge, since he was a lawful Christian born free, and whether the testifier did not know, that it was his duty immediately to inform the honourable lord commander thereof, and the fiscal, had responded to that, that he having heard the answer of the jonge, had angrily approached him, to go with him to his honourable lord commander there, and there to complain, as is stated before, and that he was asked whether he was authorized to seize that jonge?']
column6: ['Furthermore, when asked why the testifier had cause to retain the jongen, when he is after all a freeborn Christian, and whether the testifier did not know it was his duty to immediately inform the honourable lord commander and fiscal of this, he answered that he heard the answer of the jongen, and advised him to go with him to the honourable lord as soon as the Jew arrived, and to lodge his complaint there, as is stated here before, and that he could after all ask this jongen such questions.']
column7: ['Furthermore, when asked what reason the testifier had to keep the jongen, even though he had confessed to be a freeborn Christian, and whether the testifier did not know that it was his obligation to immediately report this to the honourable lord commander and the fiscal, had replied that he had heard the answer of the jongen, and had advised him firstly, when the Jew arrived, to go with him to the honourable, and there to make his complaint, as is noted before, and that he requested such request to be approved.']
column8: ["Further inquired, what reason the attorney had for detaining the young man, since he was rightly accused of being a freeborn Christian, and if the attorney did not know, it was his duty to immediately inform the E:E: lord commander and the fiscal, he replied, that he had heard the answer from the young man, and first advised him, upon the Jew's arrival, to go with him to his E:E: lord, and there to complain, as rightly stated before, and that he requested that the young man might be allowed to be questioned."]

column3: Of anders op de gedaene beschuldigingen van desen Antij aan den koning aldaer, sig op Cranganoor dan wel hier ter steede te vervoegen, en hem te verdedigen, ’t gunt niet gedaan, maar daer en tegen ’t sed:t sijn terug komst van Chettua sig onder de bescherming van een vreemden heer begeven hebbende, sig hier en daer ter schuijl gehouden heeft, tot dat gevat is geworden, blijkt immers daeruijt niet duijster, dat den gev: den voorm: Antij valslijk is beschuldigende, om was ’t mooglijk hem meede deelagtig te maeken aan de straffe, die hij gev: door ’t weg voeren, en verkopen van meergem: jongen Chacken sig schuldig gemaekt.
column4: Or otherwise, in response to the accusations of this Antij to the King there, to go to Cranganoor or to here in the city, and to defend him[self], which he had not done, but instead since his return to Chettua he had placed himself under the protection of a foreign lord, had hidden himself here and there, until he was arrested; does that after all not make clear that the prisoner is falsely accusing the aforementioned Antij, possibly to make him part of the crime, that the imprisoned made him[self] guilty by the abduction and selling of the aforementioned jongen Chacken.
column5: ['Whether he, the defendant, has not accused the aforementioned Antij to the king of there, and to add this to that in Cranganoor, or here in the city, and to defend him, this has not been done, but because of the aforementioned, when he returned to Chettua, he placed himself under the protection of a foreign lord, and has been hiding here and there, until he was caught; it is evident, therefore, that the prisoner has falsely accused the aforementioned Antij, to perhaps make him complicit in it, to the punishment, that he the prisoner might be subject to, for having abducted and sold the aforementioned jongen Chack']
column6: ['Whether, when faced with the accusations of the king in this matter, the prisoner did not flee to Cranganoor or hide here in the city, and defend himself, that has not happened, but having hidden under the protection of a foreign lord upon his return from Chettua, has hidden here and there, until he was caught, this indicates quite clearly that the prisoner is falsely accusing the aforementioned Antij, in order to share the blame, that the prisoner made himself guilty of by abducting and selling the aforementioned jongen Chacken.']
column7: ['Whether it is not apparent that the prisoner is falsely accusing the aforementioned Antij, to go to Cranganoor or here to the city to defend himself, but instead having returned there under the protection of a foreign lord, he has hidden here and there until he was caught, because indeed it appears from this that the prisoner is falsely accusing the aforementioned Antij in order to make him complicit in the punishment that the prisoner has imposed upon himself by transporting and selling the aforementioned jongen Chacken.']
column8: ['According to the accusations made by this Antij against the king there, he did not come to Cranganoor, nor did he appear here to defend him. Instead, it is said that he returned from Chettua under the protection of a foreign lord, and hid here and there until he was captured. It is indeed not surprising, given this, that the accused Antij is falsely accusing him, in order to make himself a willing participant in the punishment he is undergoing, and in the sale and trafficking of more than one young boy Chacken, whom he is accused of making guilty.']

column3: Compareerde andermael voor de naergenoemde gecommitteerde leeden uijt den E: agtb: Raad van Justitie binnen destad Cochim, den deposant in het hoofd der voorenstaende klagtdepositie gemelt, dewelke hem nu wederom ten overstaen van densecretaris der Justitie Hendrik Wendelin Koller /die mits indispositie van den fiscael deser commanderije Corijn Stevens, het fiscalaet prointerum is fungerende:/ ende in presentie van de gev:s Itti en Ittinan door mij ges: clercq onder vertaeling van den ondertolk Balthazar den Brouwer van woorde tot woorde wel ende duijdelijk voorgehouden en de te verstaen gegeven zijnde, bleef hij deposant bij den inhoude van voors: zijne verleende getuijgenisse ten vollen persisteren zonder eenige deminste veranderinge te begeeren.
column4: Appeared again before the mentioned delegated members of the aforementioned honourable Council of Justice in the city of Cochim, the deponent mentioned in the above complaint deposition, which was now again well and clearly put and explained to him word for word by me the sworn clerk by translation of the junior interpreter Balthazar den Brouwer in the presence of the secretary of the aforementioned Council Hendrik Wendelin Koller (who by indisposition of the fiscal of this district, Corijn Stevens, is serving here as fiscal prointerum) and in the presence of the prisoners Itti and Ittinan, the deponent fully persisted with the contents of their aforementioned testimony, without desiring the slightest alteration.
column5: ['Compared another time for the undermentioned delegated members of the Council of Justice within the city of Cochim, the deponent mentioned in the heading of the above-mentioned deposition, which is now again presented to him in the presence of the secretary of the Council of Justice, Hendrik Wendelin Koller (who is fulfilling the fiscal’s duties here because of the indisposition of the fiscal of this district, Corijn Stevens; the fiscal’s office is prointerum functioning), and in the presence of the prisoners Itti and Ittinan, by me written word for word clearly and plainly presented, and having been clearly and plainly explained to them word for word, the deponent declared without desiring the slightest alteration.']
column6: ['There appeared again before the undermentioned delegated members of the Council of Justice within the city of Cochim, the deponent named in the head of the aforementioned complaint deposition, which was now again well and clearly put to him word for word by me the sworn clerk in the presence of the secretary of the Council Hendrik Wendelin Koller (who by indisposition of the fiscal of this district, Corijn Stevens, is serving as fiscal and interpreter) and in the presence of the prisoners Itti and Ittinan, and when made clear to him by translation of the junior interpreter Balthazar den Brouwer, the deponent persisted fully with the contents of his aforementioned voluntary confession, without desiring the least alteration.']
column7: ['Appeared again before the undermentioned delegated members of the honourable Council of Justice in the city of Cochim, the deponent mentioned in the heading of the previous complaint deposition, which was now again well and clearly put and explained to him word for word by me the sworn clerk by translation of the junior interpreter Balthazar den Brouwer in the presence of the secretary of the aforementioned Council Hendrik Wendelin Koller (who by indisposition of the fiscal of this district, Corijn Stevens, is serving as fiscal prointerum) and in the presence of the prisoners Itti and Ittinan, the deponent fully persisted with the contents of his aforementioned voluntary confession without desiring the slightest alteration.']
column8: ['The deposant appeared again before the aforementioned committee members of the Eighth Council of Justice within the city of Cochim, in the presence of the secretary of Justice, Hendrik Wendelin Koller, who was acting as fiscal in the absence of the fiscal of this commandery, Corijn Stevens. In the presence of the witnesses Itti and Ittinan, I, the clerk, took down the deposition under the interpretation of the interpreter Balthazar den Brouwer, word for word and clearly. However, the deposant remained steadfast in the content of his previously given testimony, refusing any significant changes.']

column5: ['Having absconded from his house and service, without obtaining anyone’s permission, and [by] remaining with his grandmother in silence for three days, having been taken from there to Poettencherra by Paponettij, and having been left there by the Jesuit bishop Anthonij Pimentel, he prisoner says in the aforementioned confession under number 62, that such had occurred in leaving his assigned post, that the prisoner had told the aforementioned articulen, that such had occurred in order to find a replacement for his assigned post; that two days after the same he had begun to seek a replacement, and not finding one due to the threat of the aforementioned blows, he had come hither in order to be freed of those [threatening] blows, as is written in answer to 16, 17, 18, 21 and 23']
column6: ['From the prisoner’s house and service, and without anyone’s knowledge, the prisoner had absconded and hid with her mother for two days, after which he took flight to Poettencherra, and there let her be baptized by the Jesuit bishop Anthony Pimentel; for a more detailed account, see the confession under number 62, different from and contrary to the abandonment of his assigned post, the prisoner says in the aforementioned articles that this had happened because the commander had said to him under the threat of blows, find that meijt! The prisoner had searched for her two days, and when he did not find her, he returned here to free himself from the feared blows, see answers 16, 17, 18, 21 and 23.']
column7: ['Absconded from the prisoner’s house and service without notice, and staying quietly with her mother for three days, from there she fled to Paponettij and Poettencherra, and there the Jesuit bishop Anthonij Pimentel let her be baptized; for more see in the aforementioned confession under number 62; concerning the abandonment of his assigned post, the prisoner says in the aforementioned articles that such has been done because the commander, under the threat of blows, had said to him to find the mentioned meijt, the prisoner searched for her two days later, and not finding her out of fear for the threatened blows, came here to be free from that, see articles 16, 17, 18, 21 and 23.']
column8: ["Leaving her husband's house and her service, without his knowledge, she had absented herself for three days with her mother, living in silence. From there, she fled to Paponetti and Poettencherra. There, Bishop Anthony Pimentel of the Jesuits had her baptized. A more detailed account can be seen in her confession under number 62 of this document, stating that this happened because the commander, under the threat of beatings, had told her to seek him out two days after the same threat, and not finding relief from the feared beatings, she returned to seek freedom, as stated in articles 16, 17, 18, 21, and 23."]

column3: Onse onderdaan den Chego Canden inwoonder op S:t Andries heeft met voorkennisse van de marambins een slave meid gekogt, hij de meijd na de stad brengende om weder te verkopen, is hij, ende meijd gearresteerd, niet wetende, wat daar de reden van sij, U: E: believe de meid bij sig t[e] houden, tot onse komste op Cochim, wanne[er] wij nader met malkander daarover sullen sp[re] ken, en ondertussen den Chego Canden met bre[. . .] deses herwaarts tesenden, heeft hij daarin qualijk gedaan sullen wij hem na examinatie van zaken straffen, U: E: believe van het voorsch: rapport aan sijn E: E: agtb: te geven, en den Chego herwaarts te senden getekend bij den paljetter onderstond voor de translatie Cochim dato als boven /was get:/ C:s v: Meeckeren g: transl:.
column4: Our subject the Chego Canden, resident of Saint Andries, has with foreknowledge of the marambins bought a slave meijd; when he was bringing the meijd to the city to resell her, he and the meijd were arrested, not knowing what the reason for this was, requesting your Honourable to please keep the meijd with you, until our arrival in Cochim, when we shall speak further about this with each other, and meanwhile to send the Chego Canden with [. . .] of this here; if he has acted wrongfully therein we shall punish him after examination of the case; requesting your Honourable to please give the aforementioned rapport to his Honourable and to send the Chego hither, signed by the paljetter below, for the translation, Cochim, dated as above [was signed] C.s v. Meeckeren, sworn interpreter.
column5: ['Our subject, the Chego Canden, resident of Saint Andries, has with prior knowledge of the marambins bought a slave meid, he bringing her to the city to sell [her] again, he and the meijd were arrested, not knowing what their reason was, we will keep the meid with us until our arrival in Cochim, when we will discuss this matter more extensively with each other, and in the meantime will send the Chego Canden here, he will punish him after an examination of affairs, and give the aforementioned report to his honourable, and send him back to Cochim, dated as above, signed with the stamp of the interpreter, standing below this for the translation, Cochim, dated as above, [signed] C.s v: Meeckeren, sworn interpreter.']
column6: ['Our subject the Chego Canden resident of S.t Andries has, with approval of the marambins, bought a slave meijd, he bringing the meijd to the city to again put her up for sale, he and the meijd having been arrested, not knowing the reason for that, you honourables believe the meijd to hold until our arrival in Cochim, when we shall further investigate this together and in the meantime send the Chego Canden here, has he done poorly therein, we shall judge him after examination of the case, you honourables believe to give his honourable’s report and send the Chego here, signed by the paljetter and below understood for the translation, Cochim dated as above [was signed] C.s v. Meeckeren, sworn interpreter.']
column7: ['Our subject the Chego Canden, resident of Saint Andries, has with the knowledge of the marambins bought a slave girl, he the meijd bringing to the city to sell again, was he and the meijd arrested, not knowing the reason why they kept the meijd with them, until our arrival at Cochim, when we shall speak with each other about this matter, and in the meantime have sent the Chego Canden here with this letter, [he] has done wrong shall we examine the matter and punish him appropriately, I believe [you] to keep the aforementioned report, and to send the Chego here signed by the paljetter below for the translation, Cochim dated as above [was signed] C.s v. Meeckeren, sworn interpreter.']
column8: ['The subject, Chego Canden, resident of St. Andrews, has purchased a slave girl with foreknowledge of the marabins. Bringing the girl into the city to resell her, he and the girl were arrested, unaware of the reason for this. Upon our arrival in Cochim, we will discuss this matter further. In the meantime, we have sent Chego Canden with this letter to Cochim. Upon examination of the facts, we will punish him. We believe the girl should be kept by him until our arrival in Cochim, and upon receipt of this report, it should be given to His Excellency, and Chego should be sent to Cochim, signed by the paljetter, under the translation Cochim date as above /was written/ C:s v: Meeckeren g: transl:.']

column3: Compareerde andermaal voor de na te noemene gecommiteerde E:s leden uit denachtb:RaadvanJustititedeezerstededegevangenBarkie,indevoorenstaande confessie breeder vermeld, welke hem nu wederom ten overstaan van den koopman en fiskaal deezes goevernements de heer m:r Jan Willem Hendrik van Rossum door mij gezw: klerk van woorde te woorde distinc [. . .] voorgeleezen, en door vertaaling van den tolk Dionijs Alewijn duidlijk te verstaan gegeven zijnde, bleef daarbij ten vollen persisteeren, eerlijk met deeze verandering opde afvraage van d:e: fiskaal, hoe hij konde opgeeven dat het meisje 2: a 3: dagen bij Maleparte Marien is geweest daar zij verklaard heeft van smorgens te 5 tot savonds te 5 uur bij haar gehouden te hebben, zo verklaard hij dat het de waarheid was ‘t geen hij opgegeeven heeft Maliaparte Marian binnen gescheld en afgevraagd zijnde hoe lange het kind bij haar gebleven is, zeide zij maar een dag en beriep zich op het kind, die toen in judicio geciteerd en haar facie staande hield, dat zij vijf dagen bij Maliaparte Marian geweest is.
column4: There appeared again before the undermentioned delegated honourable members of the Council of Justice of this city the prisoner Barkie, mentioned in the above confession with more detail, which was now again read to him word for word in the presence of the merchant and fiscal of this government the lord meester Jan Willem Hendrik van Rossum by me [the] sworn clerk, and made clear by the translation of the interpreter Dionijs Alewijn, fully persisted with this, respectfully with this adjustment as per the question of the honourable fiscal how he could state that the girl stayed with Maleparte Marian for 2 or 3 days because she stated that she kept her from 5 in the morning till 5 o’clock in the evening, so he declared that which he has stated, was the truth, when Maliaparte Marian was called into the room and asked for how long the child had stayed with her, she said but a day and she referred to the child, who then was cited in judicio and maintained in her face, that she had stayed five days with Maliaparte Marian.
column5: ['Compareerde andermaal voor de na te noemene gecommiteerde E:s leden uit den achtb: Raad van Justitie desezerstededeegevangen Barkie, in de voorstaande confessie breeder vermeld, welke hem nu wederom ten overstaan van den koopman en fiscaal deseves goevernement de heer m:r Jan Willem Hendrik van Rossum door mij gezw: klerk van woorde te woorde distincteerende, en door vertaaling van den tolk Dionijs Alewijn duidlijk te verstaan gegeven zijnde, bleef daarbij ten vollen persisteeren, eerlijk met deeze verandering op de afvraage van den eersten gevraagden fiscaal, hoe hij konde opgeeven dat het meisje 2 a 3 dagen bij Maleparte Marien is geweest daar zij verklaard heeft van smorgens te 5 tot savonds te 5 uur bij haar gehouden te hebben, zo verklaard hij dat het de waarheid was ‘t geen hij opgegeeven heeft']
column6: ['There appeared again before the undermentioned delegated honourable members of the Council of Justice of this city, the prisoner Barkie, mentioned in the previous confession more extensively, which was now again presented word for word to the merchant and fiscal of this government, meester Jan Willem Hendrik van Rossum, by me the sworn clerk, and made clear by the translation of the interpreter Dionijs Alewijn, and persisted fully, honestly with this alteration, on the question of the fiscal, how he could assume that the girl had been with Maleparte Marien 2 or 3 days, which she had declared to have kept with her from 5 in the morning until 5 o’clock, that it was the truth and that he had not mentioned Maliaparte Marian, after which she was asked how long the child had been with her, she said only one day and appealed to the child, who was then cited in judicio and stood by her, that she had been with Maliaparte Marian for five days.']
column7: ['There appeared again before the undermentioned delegated honourable members of the Council of Justice of this city, the prisoner Barkie, mentioned in the previous confession, which was now again distinctly read to him word for word by me the sworn clerk in the presence of the merchant and fiscal of this government the lord meester Jan Willem Hendrik van Rossum, and was made clear by the translation of the interpreter Dionijs Alewijn, he fully persisted with this alteration when asked by the honourable fiscal, how he could state that the girl had been with Maleparte Marien for two or three days, after which she had declared to have kept her from 5 in the morning until 5 in the evening, he declared that this was the truth, when Maliaparte Marian was asked inside and asked how long the girl had been with her, she said only one day and held herself for the girl, who was then cited in judicio and, standing face to face with her, declared that she had been with Maliaparte Marian for five days.']
column8: ["He again asserted before the aforementioned committee members of the Eighteenth Council of Justice, in the aforementioned confession more broadly mentioned, which he now again, in the presence of the merchant and fiscal officer of this government, Mr. Jan Willem Hendrik van Rossum, through me, the clerk, distinctly recited, and through the interpretation of the interpreter Dionijs Alewijn clearly understood, continued to persist, honestly with this change in response to the inquiry of the fiscal officer, how he could admit that the girl had been at Maleparte Marien for 2 to 3 days, where she had declared that she had held her from morning to evening from 5 to 5 o'clock, he declared that it was the truth. However, when asked if Maliaparte Marien had sworn and inquired how long the child had stayed with her, she said only one day and appealed to the child, who was then cited in judicio and stood facing her, that she had been at Maliaparte Marien for 5 days."]

column3: Compareerde voor de naegen: gecommitteerde leeden uit den agtb: Raad van Justitie deser steede den slave jonge Apocre, voor deser sijnde geweest casta Chego met name Chacko, geboortig 5. mijlen binnen ‘slands op Panani, denwelken onder verthoning van de gev: moor Abassa, Coenje Pokre, en Cheko, die hij bekend wel te kennen, vrijwillig geconfesseert ende beleden heeft, door vertaling in de Mallabaarse taale hoe dat hij confessant heel kleen sijnde, door sijn ouders aan seeker moor tot Panani, in name Moeniaan Koedij is verkogt geworden, bij wien twee maanden verblijvende, desen Koedij hem wijders verkogt heeft aan den moor Abassa, toen ter tijd meede op Pananij woonende, edog nu omtrend vier jaaren geleden na de brand tot Pananij nae Porka vertrokken en aldaar gewoont hebbende: van welken laatsten plaatse nu omtrend 6. dagen geleden, hij confessant met voorm: sijn baas Awassa, alhier op Cochim aankomende twee dagen daarnae door denselven verder is verkogt aan de moor Cheko; die hem wederom ‘sdaags daaraan aan een Boegineese vaandrig ten koop heeft aangepresenteerd.
column4: Appeared before the undermentioned delegates of the honourable Council of Justice of this city, the slave jongen Apocre, previously having been of the casta Chego, with the name Chacko, born five miles into the land of Pannanij, who, after seeing the imprisoned Moor Bassa, Coenje Pokre and Cheko, whom he confessed to know, voluntarily confessed and admitted, by translation in the Malabarian language, how, when the confessant was very young, he was sold by his parents to a certain Moor in Panani, named Moeniaan Koedij, with whom he stayed for two months; this Koedij then sold him to the Moor Abassa, who at that time also lived in Pananij, yet now four years ago after the fire at Pananij he left for Porka and having lived there, from that place now six days ago the confessant arrived here in Cochim with his boss Awassa and two days later he was sold further by him to the Moor Cheko, who presented him for sale again the next day to a Buginese vaandrig.
column5: ['Appeared before the undermentioned delegated members of the honourable Council of Justice of this city, the slave jonge Apocre, being here before, [and] declared and confessed voluntarily by translation in the Malabarian language how that he, the confessant, being all kleen, was sold by his parents to a certain Moor at Pananij, in name Moeniaan Koedij, where he stayed for two months, [and] that the mentioned Koedij sold him to the Moor Abassa, when he was living in Pananij at the same time, [and] that now about four years ago after the fire at Pananij, he left and arrived at Porka, [and] that there he was staying for a while, [and] that now about six days ago, he the confessant arrived here in Cochim with the aforementioned his baas Awassa, [and] that two days later he was sold again by him to the Moor Cheko; [and] that now this past week an Enchewa presented him for sale to a Bogineese vaandrig.']
column6: ['There appeared before the undermentioned delegated members of the honourable Council of Justice of this city the slave jonge Apocre, formerly with caste Chego with name Chacko, born in the earth 5 miles within the land of Panani, who under presentation of the imprisoned Moor Abassa, Coenje Pokre and Cheko, has voluntarily confessed and admitted, by translation in the Malabarian language that how the confessant when very young, was sold by his parents to a certain Moor in Panani, named Moeniaan Koedij, living with whom for two months, this Koedij sold him further to the Moor Abassa, when living in the same place as Abassa in Pananij, but now about four years ago left for Porka after the fire and living there, from whom place now about six days ago, the confessant with his aforementioned owner Awassa, arrived in Cochim and after two days was sold further by him to the Moor Cheko, who presented him the next day to a Buginese vaandrig for sale.']
column7: ['There appeared before the undermentioned delegated members of the honourable Council of Justice of this city the slave jonge Apocre, who used to be a casta Chego named Chacko, born in a distance of five miles in the land of Pananij, who, upon being shown the prisoner Moor Abassa, Coenje Pokre and Cheko, whom he acknowledged to know well, voluntarily confessed and admitted, that because he, the confessant, was very small, he was sold to a certain Moor in Pananij, named Moeniaan Koedij, by his parents; with whom he stayed for two months, until this Koedij sold him further to the Moor Abassa, who at that time was also residing in Pananij, yet now about four years ago he left from there because of the fire in Pananij and arrived in Porka, and there he has been living for about six days ago, when the confessant arrived here with his aforementioned boss Awassa, and the next day he was further put up for sale to the Moor Cheko by him; who offered him the next day to a Buginese vaandrig for sale.']
column8: ["Appeared before the eyes: appointed members from the 8th Council of Justice of this place examined the slave young Apocre, who had been known as casta Chego with the name Chacko, born 5 miles within 'slands on Panani, whom, under the custody of the Moor Abassa, Coenje Pokre, and Cheko, whom he recognized, willingly confessed and declared, through translation in the Malabar language, how that he, being a small confessant, had been sold by his parents to the Moor at Panani, in name Moeniaan Koedij, was sold; while staying with him for two months, this Koedij sold him again to the Moor Abassa, who, at the time, was also living on Pananij; and now, approximately four years ago, after the fire at Pananij to Porka, he departed and lived there; from whom last place, he, the confessant, with his master Awassa, arrived here at Cochim two days ago, and was again sold the same day by him to the Moor Cheko; who presented him the next day to a Buginese officer for sale."]

column3: Den Raad met aendagt gelesen end[e] geresumeert hebbende den schriftelijken crimineelen eijsch door den koopman en fiscaal deses commandements Nicolaas Bowijn ex off: eijsser op ende jegens den gev: christen lascorijn Jano, over het wegvoeren en verkopen van een Poeliase jongen, in naeme Chacken, toebehoorende sijn hoogheis den coning van Cochim, g’exhibeert, benevens de stucken en bewijsen tot adstru[. . .] [. . .]ewonnen, mits gad[. . .] gelet op ’t geene te [. . .] en in de [. . .] ende doende [. . .] ex off: ged[a]en[e]n eijsch, en verklaert oversulxdengev:tesijneenmandesdoods,hemtendieneijndecondemneerend[e] om g[e]bragt sijnde ter ordinaire geregts plaetse, alwaer men hier gewoon is crimineel sententien te executeeren, aldaer aen den scherpregter overgelevert, en door denselven met de koorte aan den galge gestraft te werden, dat’er de dood nae volgt, en desselvs doode lichaem nae het buijten geregt gebragt, en weder aan de aldaer staende galge tot proije van de lugt en de vogelen des hemels opgehangen, cum expensis; advoueert wijders des eijssers sijn gedaen versoek om met het believen van de overigheid deser custe [. . .].
column4: The Council has read closely and repeated aloud the written criminal eijsch of the merchant and fiscal of this district, Nicolaas Bowijn, ex officio eijsser, against the imprisoned Christian lascorin Jano on the abduction and selling of a Poeliase jongen, named Chacken, belonging to his highness the king of Cochim, submitted together with the documents and evidence collected for explanation, also paying attention to that [. . .] and in the [. . .] and so doing [. . .] ex officio submitted eijsch, and declares as such the prisoner to be a dead man, convicting him for that reason to be brought to the ordinary place of execution, where criminal sentences are usually executed, there to be handed over to the executioner and to be punished by him with the rope on the gallows, until death follows, and his dead body to be brought to the outer place of execution, and there again to be hung up on the there-standing gallow to be consumed by the air and birds of the sky, cum expensis; admits further the eijsser’s made request in order to with the approval of the government of this coast [. . .].
column5: ['The Council having read and noted down the case of the scriptural criminal eijsch door den koopman en fiscaal deses commandements Nicolaas Bowijn, ex officio eijsser, against the imprisoned Christian lascorin Jano, over the abduction and selling of a Poeliase jongen, named Chacken, belonging to his highness the king of Cochim, exhibited, together with the documents and evidence obtained, with caution, so that the official, eijsser, may review this when he returns from here, and doing so, declares the imprisoned lascorin Jano, and meentes, to be guilty of the death of the aforementioned jongen Chacken, and as such condemns and sentenced him to be brought to the ordinary place of execution, where one usually executes criminal sentences, there to be punished with the knot around the neck by the executioner, until death follows, and thereafter the dead body is brought to the outer place of execution and there again is hung up on the galge by the official, cum expensis; furthermore he confesses that he requests permission, with the fulfilment of the remainder of this case, [. . .].']
column6: ['The Council having read and agreed the written criminal indictment by the merchant and fiscal of this district, Nicolaas Bowijn, ex officio eijsser, against the prisoner Christian lascorin Jano, about the abduction and selling of a Poeliase jongen, named Chacken, belonging to the highness the king of Cochim, exposed, besides the articles and evidence for conviction, with regard to what has been done here and in the [...] and doing [...] ex officio denied and condemning [that] when brought to the ordinary place of execution, where one usually executes criminal sentences, there delivered to the executioner, and by him tortured on the stake, until death follows, and his dead body brought to the outer place of execution, and again hung on the there standing stake to be devoured by the air and the birds of the sky, cum expensis; additionally pleads further the eijsser’s their done request to please the other authority of this coast [...].']
column7: ['The Council having with attention read and resumed the written criminal eijsch by the merchant and fiscal of this district, Nicolaas Bowijn, ex officio eijsscher, against the imprisoned Christian lascorin Jano, about the abduction and selling of a Poeliase jongen, named Chacken, belonging to his highness the king of Cochim, exhibited, together with the documents and proofs collected for the validation of, if possible, [. . .] [. . .]ewonnen, mits gad[. . .] gelet op ’t geene te [. . .] en in de [. . .] ende doende [. . .] ex off: ged[a]en[e]n eijsch, and declares the executioner of this sentence, whether man or woman, to be brought to the ordinary place of execution, where criminal sentences are usually executed, there to be handed over to the executioner by the eijsscher, and to be punished by him with the rope on the gallows, until death follows, and his dead body to be brought to the outer place of execution, and there once again to be hung up on the there-standing gallows as prey for the wind and the birds of the sky, cum expensis; furthermore endorses the eijsscher’s request with the favour of the government of this coast, [. . .].']
column8: ['The Council having read and resumed, the written criminal indictment by the merchant and fiscal of this commandment Nicholas Bowijn ex officio, issuer against and against the prisoner Christian Lascorijn Jan, concerning the transportation and sale of a Polish boy named Chacken, belonging to his highness the king of Cochin, exhibited, in addition to the exhibits and evidence for prosecution, if considered on the matter to be [. . .] and in the [. . .] and doing [. . .] ex officio, has issued, and declares the execution of the sentence of death, brought to the ordinary court place, where it is customary to execute criminal sentences, delivered to the executioner there, and punished by the executioner with the rope at the gallows, resulting in death, and the dead body being brought out of the court and hung on the gallows as bait for the stench and the birds of the sky, at the expense; furthermore, the request of the issuer for the permission of the authority of this coast [. . .].']

column3: Aandagtelijk gelesen en geresumeert hebbende het schriftelijke Dictum door den onderkoopman en fiscaal deses commandements Nicolaas Bowijn Ex off: Eijsser op den 2 deser in Rade van Justitie deExhibeert, Contra den Toepasse soldaat Jan Dias jo: op Chettua dienst gedaan hebbende, thans ‘sheeren gevangen over presumtief verkopen, en wegbrengen van een andermans slave meijd, en het verlaten van sijn post, waar over bij diffinitief vonnis door voorm: Raad op Gisteren gevelt, des Eijssers Eijsch, en versoek tot largatie vanden gev: kost en schadeloos uit sijn detentie, is geadvoueert, enden Lieutenant Commandant van voorm: fortresse Jan Doorn Gecondemneert in de vergoeding van des gevangens maand Gelden, die hij Geduurende Zijn detentie niet heeft genoten, mitsgaders de kosten en misen van Justitie; Maar daarentegen gesurcheert het versoek van den Eijsser aangaande deslave meid Cali als een Lijfeigen aanden landheer tot Chettua Paijencherij Nairo, en nu volgens haar voorgeven op Poettenchera gedoopt en christen geworden sijnde, met last aan voorm: officier sig naauwkeurig te Informeeren, of degem: slave meid Cali, waarlijk door de Jesuitse bisschop tot voorsch: Poettenchera Anthonij Pimentel, haar heeft laten dopen, omme vervolgens nader over deselve te disponeeren,
column4: Having attentively read and reviewed the written dictum by the second merchant and fiscal of this district, Nicolaas Bowijn, ex officio eijsser exhibited on the 2[nd] of this month in the Council of Justice, contra the Toepas soldier Jan Dias, having served in Chettua, currently the lords’ prisoner for [the] presumed selling and taking away of someone else’s slave meijd, and leaving his post, about which was passed with certain judgement by the Council, approving the eijsser’s eijsch, and request for the prisoner’s release from his detention acquitted, indemnified and gratuitously, and the lieutenant commander of the aforementioned fort Jan Doorn condemned in the compensation of the prisoner’s maandgelden, which he did not receive during his detention, as well as the costs and expenditure of justice; but on the other hand suspended the request of the eijsser regarding the slave meid Cali as a lijfeigen of the landlord of Chettua Paijencherij Nairo, and now according to her claim of having been baptized at Poettencher and become a Christian, with instruction to the aforementioned officer to accurately inquire whether the mentioned slave meid Cali truly let her[self] be baptized by the Jesuit bishop of the aforementioned Poettenchera, Anthonij Pimentel, to be able to take a decision about it thereafter.
column5: ['Anandagtelijk gelesen en geresumeert hebbende het schriftelijke Dictum door den onderkoopman en fiscaal deses commandements Nicolaas Bowijn, contra den Toepasse soldaat Jan Dias, jo: op Chettua in dienst gedaan hebbende, thans ‘sheeren gevangen over presumtief verkopen, en wegbrengen van een andermans slave meijd, en het verlaten van sijn post, waar over bij diffinitief vonnis door voorm: Raad op Gisteren gevelt, des Eijsser Eijsch, en versoek tot largatie vanden gev: kost en schadeloos uit sijn detentie, is geadvoueert, en den Lieutenant Commandant van voorm: fortresse Jan Doorn, gecondemneert in de vergoeding van des gevangens maand Gelden, die hij gedurende zijne detentie niet heeft genoten, mitsgaders de kosten en misen van Justitie;\nMaar daarentegen gesurcheert het versoek van den Eijsser aangaande deslave meid Cali, als een lijfelijk aanden landheer tot Chettua Paijencherij Nairo, en nu volgens haar voorgeven op Poettenchera gedoopt en christen geworden']
column6: ['Attentively read and summarized the written Dictum by the second merchant and fiscal of this district, Nicolaas Bowijn, ex officio Eijsser, on 2nd of this month in the Council of Justice, theExhibeert, contra the Toepasse soldier Jan Dias jo: on Chettua served, now the lords’ prisoners over presumptively selling, and taking away someone else’s slave meijd, and the abandonment of his post, about which the definite judgment was handed down by the aforementioned Council yesterday, the Eijsser’s complaint, and request for release of the prisoner free from costs and compensation from his detention, is endorsed, and signed the Lieutenant Commander of the aforementioned fort Jan Doorn, Condemned in the repayment of the prisoner’s maand gelden, that he did not receive during his detention, as well as the costs and expenses of Justice; But contrary to the request of the Eijsser concerning the slave meid Cali as a lijfeigen to the landlord of Chettua Paijencherij Nairo, and now according to her claim raised in Poettenchera baptized and become Christian, with instruction to the aforementioned officer to accurately inquire whether the mentioned slave meid Cali truly let herself be baptized by the Jesuit bishop of the aforementioned Poettenchera Anthonij Pimentel, to thereby further dispose of her.']
column7: ['Having attentively read and summarized the written dictum by the second merchant and fiscal of this district, Nicolaas Bowijn, Ex officio eijsscher, Contra the Toepasse soldier Jan Dias, who has served on Chettua, currently the lord’s prisoner, over presumptively selling and taking away someone else’s slave meijd, and for leaving his post, about which the aforementioned Council of Justice passed definitive judgement in favour of the eijsscher’s request for release from prison free from cost and compensation yesterday, the lieutenant commander of the aforementioned fort, Jan Doorn, has been condemned in the amount of the prisoner’s maand money, which he did not enjoy during his detention, as well as the costs and expenditure of justice; But on the other hand, the eijsscher’s request for the slave meid Cali to be treated as a lijfeijgenen ad landheer tot Chettua Paijencherij Nairo, and now according to her claim of having been baptized at Poettenchera and become a Christian, with instruction to aforementioned officer to accurately inform himself about whether the aforementioned slave meid Cali has truly been baptized by the Jesuit bishop of the aforementioned Poettenchera, Anthonij Pimentel, in order to be able to decide about her thereafter.']
column8: ["Having attentively read and summarized the written decree by the under-commissioner and fiscal of this commandment, Nicholas Bowijn, Ex officio: Issuer on the 2nd of this month in the Council of Justice, Exhibited, Contra den Toepasse soldier Jan Dias, who has served on Chettua, is now imprisoned on the presumption of selling and transporting another man's slave maid, and abandoning his post, for which a definitive verdict by the previous Council on Yesterday has been issued, the Issuer's Eijsch, and request for remission of the imprisonment cost and damages from his detention, has been proposed, and Lieutenant Commandant of the previous fortress, Jan Doorn, has been condemned in the payment of the imprisonment money, which he did not enjoy during his detention, in addition to the costs and expenses of Justice; but on the contrary, the request of the Issuer regarding the slave maid Cali, as a lifelong slave to the landlord to Chettua Paijencherij Nairo, and now, according to her claim, baptized and converted in Poettenchera, is sought, and it is requested that the aforementioned slave maid Cali, in truth, was baptized by the Jesuit bishop to Poettenchera, Anthonij Pimentel, in order to dispose of her subsequently. column3: Compareerde andermael voor de naegenoemde gecommitteerde leeden uijt voorsz: agtb: Raed van Justitie den confessant in het hoofd der voorenstaende confessie gemelt, dewelke hem nu wederom ten overstaen van den sec:s uijt voormelte Rade Hend:k Wendelin Koller /die mits indispositie van den fiscael deser commanderije Corijn Stevens het fiscalaet in desen prointerum is fungerende/ ende in presentie van den mede gev: den Caniaan Ittinaen door mij gesw: clerq onder vertaeling van den ondertolk Balthazar den Brouwer van woorde tot woorde wel ende duijdelijk voorgehouden ende te verstaen gegeven zijnde, bleef hij confessant bij den inhoude van voorsz: zijne vrijwillige confessie ten vollen persisteren, zonder eenige deminste veranderinge te begeeren, met dese amplicatie nogthans dat eer en bevorens zij de koop in de schagerije beslooten hebben, en nog een Caniaan in name Ittinaen Coenje, met haar en [d:o] gepretendeerde slaef binnen destad en in zeker huijs van een blank vrouwspersoon gekomen is, en de prijs willende maken van verkoop, en daar mede niet kunnende accorderen, zijt tesamen na buijten zijn gegaen, tot aan de brugh van Calawette, alwaer ged:te Caniaan de gev:s belast heeft om de jongen in questie in de stad te brengen en verkoopen, waarna d:o Caniaan is heenen gegaen.
column4: Appeared again before the undermentioned delegated members of the aforementioned Council of Justice the confessant mentioned in the heading of the previous confession, which was now again well and clearly put and explained to him word for word by me the sworn clerk by translation of the junior interpreter Balthazar den Brouwer in the presence of the secretary of the aforementioned Council Hend.k Wendelin Koller (who by indisposition of the fiscal of this district, Corijn Stevens, is serving here as fiscal pro interum) and in the presence of the co-prisoner Caniaan Ittinaen, the confessant fully persisted with the contents of his aforementioned voluntary confession, without desiring the least alteration, yet with this addition that before they had concluded the purchase in the schagerije, and another Caniaan named Ittinaen Coenje came into the city and into a certain house of a white woman with her and dito alleged slave, and wanting to establish the price of sale, and not being able to agree on it, they went outside together, to the bridge of Calawette, where the defendant Caniaan had ordered the prisoners to bring and sell the jongen in question in the city, after which the mentioned Caniaan left.

column8: ["The confessant, again, appeared before the aforementioned committee members, namely the chief of the aforementioned confession, who is presently the acting fiscal of the commander's court, Corijn Stevens, in the presence of the second secretary of the aforementioned council, Hendrick Wendelin Koller, and in the presence of the co-defendant, the Canarian Ittinaen, who was sworn in by me as a witness, under the interpretation of the interpreter Balthazar den Brouwer, word for word and clearly stated and given to understand, remained a confessant, persisting fully in the content of the aforementioned voluntary confession, without desiring any significant changes, with this addition, however, that they decided on the sale in the marketplace before their honor and dignity, and another Canarian in the name of Ittinaen Coenje, with her and [his] pretended slave within the city and in a certain house of a white woman, came, and wished to make a sale, and could not come to an agreement, went together outside, to the bridge of Calawette, where the aforementioned Canarian charged the guards to bring the boy in question into the city and sell him, after which the aforementioned Canarian went away."]

column3: Compareerde voor de naergenoemde gecommitteerde leeden uijt den E: agtb: Raed van Justitie deser steede, den heijdens Caniaen Comen geboortig van Coeroernaddoe oud 32: jaeren, onderdaen van den koning van Cochim, den welken door vertaeling van den ondertolk Balthazar den Brouwer onder vertooninge van de gev:s Ittij en Ittinaen, /die hij deposant betuijgt beijde de eijgenste t’wesen over wien hij thans is klagende:/ klagender wijse heeft tekennen gegeven dat hij deposant met boven gem: Ittij hem in swagerschap bestaende van voorm: Coeroernaddoe na Illoewene opsijn gedaen versoek bij sijn broeder Conden is gegaen, dog denselven niet te huijs gevonden hebbende, sijnse met hun beijde voorts na Paloertij vertrocken, alwaer sij ontmoeten hebben den aldaer woonende Canniaen hem deposant bij naeme onbekend benevens den tweeden gev: in desen Ittinaen; dat wijders sij met hun vieren van gem: Paloertij na destad sijn gegaen, daer komende begaven sij gesamentlijk met den deposant na twee â drie huijsen, en eijndel: na de groote schagerije, dat ondertussen den deposant ook gesien heeft voors: Caniaen een ola gesch: en deselve aen des deposants swager Ittij overgegeven heeft, niet wetende ten wat eijnde, dat binnen de schagerije gekomen sijnde, den deposant verstaen heeft hij verkogt zouden werden, als wanneer den deposant daer tegens heeft geprotesteert, met betuijging van geen slaef te wesen maer een vrijgeboorene, dat vervolgens sij tesaemen door seker Toepas na den E: fiscael sijn gebragt, aldaer g’examineerd, en voorts na ‘t gevangen huijs gesonden geworden.
column4: Appeared before the aforementioned delegated members of the honourable Council of Justice of this city, the heathen Caniaen Comen, born in Coeroernaddoe, aged 32 years, subject of the king of Cochim, who by translation of the junior interpreter Balthazar den Brouwer under display of the prisoners Ittij and Ittinaen (whom the deponent professed to be the ones about whom he iscurrentlycomplaining),complainedthatthedeponentwiththeaforementioned Ittij related to him as brother-in-law went to his brother Conden from Coeroernaddoe to Illoewene at his request, but not having found him at home, they both then set out to Paloertij, where they met the Canniaen living there unknown by name to the deponent and the second prisoner in this, Ittinaen; that furthermore the four of them went from the mentioned Paloertij to the city, and coming there they proceeded jointly with the deponent to two or three houses, and finally to the big schagerije, that meanwhile the deponent also saw the aforementioned Caniaen write an ola and hand it over to the deponent’s brother- in-law, not knowing for what purpose, that having come inside the schagerije, the deponent understood he would be sold, and when the deponent protested against this, declaring to be not a slave but a freeborn, that thereafter they were jointly brought to the honourable fiscal by a certain Toepas, examined there and sent further to the prison.
column5: ['Appeared before the undermentioned delegated members of the Council of Justice of this city, the heathens Caniaen Comen, born in Coeroernaddoe, 32 years old, subjects of the king of Cochim, who by translation of the junior interpreter Balthazar den Brouwer, after display of the prisoners Ittij and Ittinaen (who he the deponent confesses were accompanying the aforementioned Coeroernaddoe at Illoewene, upon whose request the deponent has gone to his brother-in-law Conden, but not having been able to find him in his house, [and] thus continuing their journey to Paloertij, where they met the one living there, a Canniaen, [and] the aforementioned Ittinaen being brought to the deponent by the aforementioned name, that this deponent was travelling with them to the aforementioned city, that there came along four or five houses, and [that] the aforementioned Ittij ended the protest of the deponent, that he was not [a] slave but a freeborn, that thereupon this deponent stopped [from] selling, [and] thus appearing before the aforementioned Toepas, this deponent was brought to the honourable fiscal.']
column6: ['There appeared before the undermentioned delegated members of the honourable Council of Justice of this city, the heathen Caniaen Comen, born in Coeroernaddoe, 32 years of age, subject of the king of Cochim, whom the deponent has identified by translation of the junior interpreter Balthazar den Brouwer, [and] shown to him the prisoners Ittij and Ittinaen, /who, the deponent says, are the same persons he is complaining about now:/ the deponent has notified that he, the deponent, with the aforementioned Ittij had left for Illoewene in Swagerschap from the aforementioned Coeroernaddoe, but having not found his brother Conden at home, they then all four had left for Paloertij, where they met the Canniaen who lived there, the deponent unknown to him by name as well as the second prisoner in this Ittinaen; that furthermore they all five had come from the aforementioned Paloertij to the city, coming collectively with the deponent to the second or third houses, and finally to the large schagerije, that in the meantime the deponent had seen the aforementioned Caniaen giving an ola to the deponent’s swager Ittij, not knowing the purpose, that within the schagerije having come, the deponent had understood that they would be sold, when the deponent had protested against this, declaring not to be a slave but a freeborn, that thereafter they together were brought to the honourable fiscal by certain Toepas, having been examined there, and then sent to prison.']
column7: ['There appeared before the undermentioned delegated members of the honourable Council of Justice of this city, the heathen Caniaen Comen, born in Coeroernaddoe, 32 years of age, subject of the king of Cochim, who, through the translation of the junior interpreter Balthazar den Brouwer, under display of the prisoners Ittij and Ittinaen (who the deponent declared to be the same persons he is currently accusing), signed in a manner indicating that the deponent, living in swagership with the aforementioned Ittij in the aforementioned Coeroernaddoe, went to Illoewene after requesting his brother Conden, however not finding him at home, left with them both for Paloertij, where they met the Canniaen with an unknown name and the second prisoner in this, Ittinaen; that they further went with them four to the city, coming to the big schagerije, that meanwhile the deponent has seen the aforementioned Caniaen write an ola and handed it over to the deponent’s brother-in-law Ittij, not knowing for what purpose, that when they entered the schagerije, the deponent understood he would be sold, when the deponent protested against this, with the declaration of not being a slave but a freeborn, that they were then all together brought to a certain Toepas by the honourable fiscal, examined there, and later sent to prison.']
column8: ["Before the aforementioned committee members of the E: 18th Council of Justice of this place, the aforementioned Caniaen Comen, born in Coeroernaddoe and 32 years old, in the presence of the king of Cochim, whom he identifies as a deposant through the interpretation of the interpreter Balthazar den Brouwer and the presentation of the witnesses Ittij and Ittinaen, who he claims are both present over whom he is currently accusing:/ accuser:/ has given signs that he, the deposant, with the aforementioned Ittij, formerly of Coeroernaddoe, went to his brother Conden, but not finding him at home, they then went to Paloertij, where they encountered the aforementioned Caniaen, whose name the deposant does not know, along with the second witness in this Ittinaen; furthermore, they went with their four from Paloertij to the aforementioned place, where they came together with the deposant to two or three houses, and finally to the great market, where the deposant saw the aforementioned Caniaen selling oil and gave it to the deposant's slave Ittij, not knowing what the purpose was, that within the market he heard he would be sold, as when the deposant protested against this, with the assertion that he was not a slave but a freeborn, they were then brought before a certain Toepas before the E: fiscal, where they were examined, and later sent to the prison house."]

column3: Compareerde voor de natenoemene gecommitteerde leden uit den achtbaaren Raad van Justitsie deezer stede, de weduwe van den oosterschen kapitain Bappa Salia, in name Kananoe; van Kolumbo, van competenten ouderdom, en de mahomedaansche relisie toegedaan, dewelke ter requisietsie van den koopman en fiskaal deezes goevernements de heer m:r Jan Willem Hendrik van Rossum, en door vertaaling van den tolk Dionijs Alewijn verklaarde; dat de christen Malabaar Parambil Barkie aan haar 12: ropijen schuldig was; geleend voor 2: maanden; dat zij hem dikwils daarom aangesprooken doch niets gekreegen had; dat hij onderdaags met een meisje haar deur voorbijgegaan was, dat zij hem toen om het geld aangesprooken had, dat hij daarop gezegd had, thans geen geld te hebben, dat zij toen gerepliceerd had, laat het meisje zoo lange hier, tot dat gij mijn geld bezorgd, dat geschied is; dat 2 â 3 dagen de was vrouw, Madi genaamd, bij haar gekomen was om vuilgoed te haalen, dat de wasvrouw toen gevraagd had, hoe de comparante aan gerepte meisje quam, die zij voor haar kind aan genoomen had om op te trekken; dat zij geantwoord had: een Malabaar heeft het meisje hier gebragt, die mij geld schuldig is; waarop de wasvrouw gezegd had, dien Malabaar kenne ik en zal hem gaan opzoeken; dat de wasvrouw zulx haar man gezegd had, die daarop was geen gegaan om den Malabaar optevatten, dat de man hem toen binnen gebragt had bij den heer fiskaal; dat de heer fiskaal toen na rechterlijk onderzoek het meisje van de comparante had laaten afhaalen.
column4: There appeared before the undermentioned delegated honourable members of the honourable Council of Justice of this city, the widow of the Oosterschen kapitain Bappa Salia, named Kananoe; from Kolumbo, of competent age, and belonging to the Mohammedan religion, who stated on the request of the merchant and fiscal of this government the lord meester Jan Willem Hendrik van Rossum, and by translation of the interpreter Dionijs Alewijn; that the Christian Malabarian Parambil Barkie owed her 12 ropijen; borrowed for 2 months; that she addressed him often about this, but did not receive anything; that he recently passed by her door together with a girl, that she then addressed him concerning the money, that he then said, that he currently had no money, that she then replied, leave the girl here for the time being, until you have brought me the money, which happened; that two or three days [later] the wasvrouw, named Madi, arrived at her place to collect laundry, that the wasvrouw then asked, how the deponent came to be in possession of the mentioned girl, whom she had taken to raise as her child; that she had answered: a Malabarian who owes me money has brought the girl here; upon which the wasvrouw had said, I know that Malabarian and I shall visit him; that the wasvrouw told this to her husband, who then went to capture the Malabarian, that the man then brought him in to the lord fiscal; that the lord fiscal then after judicial investigation took the girl from the deponent.
column5: ['Appeared before the delegated members of the Council of Justice of this city, the widow of the Oosterschen kapitain Bappa Salia, in name Kananoe; from Kolumbo, of competent seniors, and the mahomedadans religious confession, which for the requisition of the merchant and fiscal of this government the lord meester Jan Willem Hendrik van Rossum, and by translation of the interpreter Dionijs Alewijn declared; that the Christian Malabaar Parambil Barkie owed her 12 ropijen; lent for 2 months; that she had then often addressed him about this matter, however had received nothing; that he had then left with a meisje her door; that she had then addressed him about the money, that he had answered that he did not have any money then, that she had then replied leave the meisje here with you until you have given me my money, that this had been done; that 2 or 3 days ago the was vrouw, Madi named, had come to her to collect dirty laundry, that the was vrouw had then asked how the deponent had acquired the mentioned girl, who she had taken for her own child to raise; that she had answered, that a Malabaar had brought the girl here, who owed her money; to which the was vroux had replied, I know that Malabaar and I will go and look for him; that the was vroux had then told this to her husband, who had then not gone to find the Malabaar, that the lord fiscal had then been called in to investigate this matter.']
column6: ['There appeared before the undermentioned delegated members of the honourable Council of Justice of this city, the widow of the Oosterschen kapitain Bappa Salia, in name Kananoe; from Kolumbo, of competent age, and the Mahomedaansche religie to which she belonged, which, upon request of the merchant and fiscal of this government the lord meester Jan Willem Hendrik van Rossum, and by translation of the interpreter Dionijs Alewijn, declared that the Christian Malabaar Parambil Barkie owed her 12 ropijen; (that) which she had often borrowed for two months; that she had often addressed him about it, but received nothing; that he the next day had walked by her door with a girl, that she had then addressed him about the money, that he had replied, I do not have any money, that she had then replied, leave the girl here, until you give me my money, that had happened; that 2 to 3 days the wasser woman, Madi named, had come to her to collect dirty laundry, that the wasser woman then had asked how the comparante had acquired the mentioned girl, that she had answered, a Malabaar has brought the girl here, who owes me money; to which the wasser woman had said, I know that Malabaar and will find him; that the wasser woman had said such to her husband, who then went out to seize the Malabaar, that the man then brought him to the lord fiscal; that the lord fiscal then, after judicial examination, had sent the girl away from the comparante.']
column7: ['There appeared before the undermentioned delegated members of the honourable Council of Justice of this city, the widow of the Oosters kapitain Bappa Salia, named Kananoe; of Kolumbo, of competent age, and of the Mahomedaan religion, who by request of the merchant and fiscal of this government the sir meester Jan Willem Hendrik van Rossum, and by translation of the interpreter Dionijs Alewijn, declared; that the Christian Malabarian Parambil Barkie owed the widow 12 ropijen, loaned for two months; that she had addressed him about this often, but received nothing; that he had walked by her doorstep with a girl on the previous day, that she then addressed him about the money, that he had then said, I do not have any money; that she had then replied, leave the girl here until you give me my money; that this happened 2 or 3 days ago; that the wasvrouw, named Madi, had come to her house to fetch dirty laundry; that the wasvrouw had then asked how the testifier had acquired the mentioned girl, that she had taken her for her own child to raise; that she had answered: a Malabarian has brought the girl here, who owes me money; upon which the wasvrouw had said: I know that Malabarian and will go to fetch him; that the wasvrouw had then told her husband, who had then brought the Malabarian into the house of the lord fiscal; that the lord fiscal had then by judicial inspection sent the girl back to the testifier.']
column8: ['The widow of the eastern captain Bappa Salia, known as Kananoe; of Columbus, of competent age and of the Mahommedan religion, who was requisitioned by the merchant and fiscal officer of this government, Mr. Jan Willem Hendrik van Rossum, and declared by the interpreter Dionijs Alewijn; testified that the Christian Malabar Parambil Barkie owed her 12 rijksdaalders; borrowed for 2 months; that she had often asked him for the money but received nothing; that he had passed by her house with a girl yesterday, that she had then asked him for the money, that he had then said he had no money, that she had then replied, let the girl stay here until you bring me my money, which has happened; that 2 or 3 days ago, the washerwoman, Madi named, had come to her house to collect dirty laundry, that the washerwoman had then asked how the comparant had come to the repentant girl, which she had taken for her child to take care of; that she had answered: a Malabar had brought the girl here, who owes me money; whereupon the washerwoman had said, I know that Malabar and will go to find him; that the washerwoman had told her husband, who had not gone to apprehend the Malabar, that the man had then brought the Malabar before the fiscal; that the fiscal had then, after a legal investigation, allowed the girl to be taken from the comparant.']
